trial_identification.scientifictitle: A randomised double-blind, placebo-controlled intervention trial to study the effect of iodine supplementation on breast milk iodine concentration and iodine status in lactating women and their breast-fed infants

interventions.interventions: Random allocation of placebo, iodine (75 micrograms/day), or iodine (150 micrograms/day) supplements to lactating women for the first six months of lactation.

secondaryOutcome.outcome: Iodine status of mothers and babies.
secondaryOutcome.timepoint: After six months of maternal supplementation.

eligibility.inclusivecriteria: Commitment to six months of breast-feeding.
eligibility.exclusivecriteria: No known thyroid disease. Not taking iodine containing dietary supplements. Singleton birth. Premature (<38 weeks) birth.

trial_design.concealment: Randomised, double-blind allocation placebo and iodine supplements (75 micrograms 150 microgram) in coded containers
trial_design.sequence: The random allocation sequence was generated by Microsoft Excel. The restriction method was a randomised block.

sponsorship.primarysponsorname: University of Otago, Dunedin, New Zealand
sponsorship.primarysponsoraddress: Department of Human Nutrition University of Otago Dunedin, New Zealand 9054

fundingsource.fundingaddress: Division of Sciences University of Otago Dunedin, New Zealand 9054
Otago Medical Research Foundation PO Box 5077 Dunedin, New Zealand 9058

ethicsAndSummary.summary: New Zealand has low soil iodine and the NZ diet can be low in iodine. Breastfeeding women need to get enough iodine in their diet so that they make milk with sufficient levels of iodine. This study will measure the amount of iodine in breastmilk in women who are taking a placebo (i.e. Is there enough iodine in the diet of breastfeeding NZ women now?) or iodine containing supplement (i.e. If not, will more iodine in the diet make the iodine levels in their breastmilk increase?).
ethicsAndSummary.publication: Mulrine HM, Skeaff SA, Ferguson EL, Gray AM, Valeix P. Breast milk iodine concentration declines over the first six months postpartum in iodine-deficient women. American Journal of Clinical Nutrition 92;849-56 (2010)
